div.p: 15. V. Tuesday— Quincy—

I resume the Diary in this Book after interruption from the 5th. of March, during which it has been kept on sheets which I could take with me to and from the house from day to day— Perhaps that is the best form in which a Diary can be kept— It is certainly the most convenient, at the time of keeping; though not the best for preservation— Mr Whitney, the Minister of the Congregational Church paid me a morning visit— By agreement with his Parishioners he has reduced his Salary from 750 dollars to 500 dollars a year, and other persons are engaged to preach for him about half the time— A young man by the name of Lunt has been preaching for several weeks till last Sunday when Dr Gray of Jamaica Plains performed the services— I met him as he was returning home, on my way from Dedham— There has been erected since the last Autumn a new and fourth house of worship in this town of Quincy— An Orthodox, or Calvinistic Church— They are now Unitarian, Episcopal, Universalist, and Orthodox; and the Universalists have dismissed Mr Morse, who was not sufficiently thorough going to suit their taste, and have a Mr Smith in his place— There is a Mr Leach at the Episcopal Church— The Calvinists have none yet settled.— I wrote Letters to Fisher A. Kingsbury, and to Lieutt. Thomas B. Adams— My Son Charles came out from Boston and dined and spent the remainder of the day with me— He and his wife, and two children are passing the Summer with his wife’s father Mr Peter C. Brooks at Medford. This afternoon and Evening were showery with thunder and lightning; which confined us to the House— After breakfast this morning, I visited my Garden, and found amidst the enormous growth of weeds, a number of seedling plants of the last year, and many that have come up the present Season— But a large portion of those that I had set out last October, and among them several very fine trees are dead— I have much anxiety for the proper disposal of my time, until the approach of Winter shall call me again to Washington—and a deep, though most fruitless impression of the duties of advancing age—
16. V. Wednesday

Weather still above Summer heat— Fahrenheit at 94; and time wasted, I know not how— Alpheus Spear was here this morning, and settled with me for three Quarters rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to the first of this Month— I spent an hour in the garden, and found several seedlings from my last years Plantations. My Son Charles, left me this afternoon to return to Medford— About Sunset, I bathed and swam about five minutes at the Creek wharf, and had an Evening visit from Mr Thomas Greenleaf— I wrote a short Letter to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams covering one to him from his Guardian Phineas Foster— But that which absorbed the largest portion of the day, was a research respecting the Origin of Committees of
Correspondence, in the approach of our War for Independence— George Tucker professor of Moral Philosophy at the University of Virginia recently wrote me a Letter of enquiry upon this Subject— He is writing the Life of Thomas Jefferson, and enquires whether any Committees of Correspondence were appointed by the Legislature of the Colony of Massachusetts Bay before 1773.— Jefferson claims the invention of Committees of Correspondence for Virginia, and it has become a controverted point of History. Tucker cites in his Letter to me Marshall’s life of Washington—Gordon, Mrs Warren, and Samuel A. Welles— I referred to Gordon and Marshall—to Hutchinson’s third Volume, the Massachusetts State Papers from 1764 to 1775. Tudor’s life of Otis and Alden Bradford’s History— And as almost invariably happens upon a consultation of books to verify a fact, or authenticate a recital I became so much engaged in the research that it nearly consumed the day.
17. IV:45 Thursday— From Quincy to Boston and Medford.

I wrote this morning a short Letter to Commodore Morris, enclosing my own, and in it that of Mr Phineas Foster to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams. Copying my own Letters, and writing part of the Diary of yesterday, consumed the early morning. At ten I went with Wilson and the Coach into Boston— The first person whom I met in the Street was Dr George Parkman, who invited me to dine with him, but I was engaged to go to Medford— I called at my Son Charles’s Office and saw him— Then went to the State-House, and in the Secretary’s Office. I saw Mr Bangs, and extracted from the Journal of the House of Representatives of the Province of Massachusetts Bay, of the 6th of November 1770. the entry of an order for the appointment of a Committee of Correspondence; to correspond with the Agent of the Province and others in England with the Speakers of the several Assemblies, and with Committees of Correspondence appointed, or who might be appointed by them— There was a Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University in the Council of Chamber at half past 12. I found them in Session and the President, Mr Quincy giving them an account of the recent disturbances among the Students— He said among other things that he was not at Liberty to mention what the faculty had determined upon the whole affair; but that it would be made public to-morrow— The Senior Class had been allowed to go to their respective homes without being informed whether they would have a commencement or not. Mr James Trecothick Austin, the Attorney General of the Commonwealth made some acerbated remarks upon Mr Quincy’s Statement; and Mr Alexander H. Everett expressed surprized that the President should have declined communicating to the Board, what had been the determination of the Faculty; although it was to be made publicly known to-morrow— But this Meeting was held; by a regular By-Law, more than thirty days before Commencement, to consider of the honorary
degrees proposed by the Corporation to be then conferred—and the subject of the disturbances was not even properly before the Meeting for discussion— I made this remark as serving to justify the President, for his omission to make a full Report to this Meeting on the disorders of recent occurrence, and observed that I could readily concern there might be very good reasons for the Faculty to withhold a premature report of their proceedings— It had been agreed that the meeting should be adjourned to the 21st. of August to receive the report of a Committee of three upon the proposed honorary degrees.— Mr George Blake however thought it would be necessary that there should be an earlier meeting to consider of the disturbances, and at his motion it was agreed that the Meeting should be adjourned to this day fortnight, the 31st. of July at ten O’Clock in the Morning—when President Quincy engaged to be prepared with a full report upon the subject— He agreed to this with some reluctance—complaining of having been much overburthened with labour, and of having expected to enjoy some relaxation during the vacation— It was two O’Clock when the Meeting adjourned— My Carriage was then waiting for me at the gate, and took me with Charles to Mr Brooks’s at Medford—to dine— There I found Charles’s wife with their two Children— Mr and Mrs Edward Everett, Edward and Peter C. Brooks junr. Mr N. L. Frothingham, and a young man named M’Cracken from New-York, were of the dinner company; they all returned home in the Evening; but I remained to pass the Night at Medford— We had been overtaken by a copious Shower between Boston and Medford, and there was a heavy thundergust while we were at dinner— The evening was damp and sultry, so that it confined us to the house.
18. V. Friday— From Medford to Boston and Quincy.

I took a shower bath this Morning, and walked round the grounds of Mr Brooks’s Garden— After Breakfast I came with my Son Charles to Boston— Called upon Dr George Parkman who shewed me seventy-five plates which he has just received from England of Audubon’s work upon American Ornithology— He related to me also several anecdotes concerning Audubon himself. He then walked with me into State Street where I viewed the front of the Suffolk Bank, a new Building with four fluited Pillars of Quincy Granite, of the Ionic Order— In State Street I met Mr Abbott Lawrence, with whom I went to the U.S. Branch Bank, and saw Mr N. Biddle— He came yesterday from Newport, and proposes to return to-morrow— He was with a convocation of Bank President’s and Directors, with whom after a few minutes I left him— At my Son Charles’s Office, I saw Isaac P Davis, P. P. F. Degrand, and Dr. George Parkman, who engaged me to dine with him, after the Meeting of the Overseers of the University on the 31st— At one O’Clock I went to Mr. James H. Foster’s where I saw his daughters Elizabeth and Mary— Charles came there with the Carriage, and then parted from me, to return this Evening to Medford— I came home
and at half past two dined alone— I found a Letter from my wife dated on the 13th. with unwelcome tidings of the state of health of her brother T. B. Johnson, of my Son John and of his wife— I learnt yesterday with surprize, by Mr N. Frye’s card left at Charles’s Office, that he had passed through Boston the day before on his way from Washington to Fryeburg— My wife intended to have come on with him; but her Letter says nothing of his departure— The weather since yesterday has become very cool; my thermometer in my chamber standing at 72— I employed the afternoon in reading and writing—visited my Garden towards Sunset, and then spent an hour of the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s; where I met Dr Woodward, and Mr Beale with his eldest daughter Ann.— Then returned to my Solitude and repose—
19. V. Saturday.

William Spear came this Morning and discoursed to me an hour or two upon various matters relating to my estate and affairs here— They are tedious, and irksome, and thorny—and I would gladly escape from them but cannot— I suffer by carelessness and inattention to them. Mr Spear gave me much good advice, and apprised me of various depredations committed upon my property—the remedy for which would be attention. This I resolved to give, as I have often resolved before— My nephew John Quincy was here, and Mr Bailey and Mr Joseph Morton paid me a morning visit— I passed the day at home, with a morning and afternoon call in my Garden— My seedling trees increase in number; but many of them annually perish— I finally wrote of Mr George Tucker, and enclosed to him a copy of the order upon the Journal of the House of Representatives of the Province of Massachusetts-Bay of 7. Novr. 1770. appointing a Committee of Correspondence to correspond with the Agent of the Province in England—with the Speakers of the several Assemblies of the other Colonies or with Committees of Correspondence appointed by them— The claim of Mr Jefferson to these Committees of Correspondence, as a Virginian invention, is like the claim of Amerigo Vespucci to the discovery of the new Hemisphere— This search engaged me again in the perusal of the Journal of the Massachusetts House of Representatives of the year 1773, and of the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History, both of which I went cursorily through; with occasional reference to Alden Bradford’s history of Massachusetts from 1764 to 1775— Hutchinson’s History is such a tale of humiliations and discomfitures to the author that it is scarcely conceivable how he should have had the patience to write it, or the courage to leave it in manuscript to survive him— It is a precious historical memorial as the narrative of the origin and progress of the American revolution, by the most effective Agent on the Royal side, in producing it— Himself too a native of the Colonies—the Representative not only of the Transatlantic Government, but of the portion of the Colonial population which adhered to the mother Country and her cause— The day was so much absorbed by this reading, that I had only the Evening to write to my wife.
20. V. Sunday—

Copied into my Letter-Book the Letter written last Evening to my wife— This is noisome, and to me useless labour, consuming time which might be fruitfully employed— But in my father’s first Letter-Book, I find him saying on the 2d. of June 1776 that in all the correspondences he had maintained, during a course of twenty years at least that he had been a writer of Letters, he never kept a single copy. And he adds— This negligence and inaccuracy has been a great misfortune to him on many occasions.— A Letter Book—a Diary—a Book of receipts and expenses—these three Books, kept without intermission, should be the rule of duty of every man who can read and write— But to keep them perseveringly requires a character given to very few of the Sons of men— Above all it requires a character to which toil is a pleasure, and of which untiring Patience is an essential Element.— I heard Mr P. Whitney in the morning from Ecclesiastes 9.5. “For the living know that they shall die: but the dead knows not any thing, neither have they any more a reward: for the memory of them is forgotten.” A Sermon upon Death.— A monition? The text contains one of those passages, of which there are many in the writings of Solomon, and in the Psalms, and which seem to deny a future state of existence— But there are many other passages in the same Books importing and even affirming, the immortality of the Soul— The most remarkable and emphatic of which is in the twelfth chapter of this Book of Ecclesiastes, and the 7th. verse— Mr Whitney’s afternoon discourse was from 1. Corinthians 13.12. [“]For now, we see through a glass darkly.” There was a collection at the close of the afternoon service, to purchase books for the Sunday School.— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with me— Evening visit from Mr Daniel Greenleaf— I read the 8th. Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin—upon the participation of Christians in the exaltation of Jesus Christ—preached on Ascension day— And I wrote a short Letter to James M’Cally at Clarksburg, Virginia.
21. V. Monday.

Visited my garden this morning after Breakfast. My nephew John Quincy brought me the Mail— There was a Letter from my wife— Her brother—our son John and his wife Mary are all sick— She says nothing of her intention to come on— I wrote two Letters—one to Samuel Brown, and one to E. Kirby, both at Brownville, and in answer to Letters from them, relating to the Monument to be erected over the remains of General Brown at Washington— They urge me to write the obituary Inscription; a task from which I should have been glad to be relieved, but which I have nevertheless consented to undertake.— General Brown is one of those men, who have rendered eminent services to this Country, and to whom full Justice has not been rendered in return. He was a native of Pennsylvania, and it is a very remarkable fact that the People of that State, whose fanatical passion for Andrew Jackson can be compared to nothing but that of Titania Queen of the Fairies, for Bottom, after his Assification, never manifested the slightest regard, or gave a single token of gratitude to him. He made
this remark once, himself, with deep and indignant feeling, to me— He said nothing of Jackson, or of the senseless devotion to him of the Pennsylvanians— But he knew that his own services had been more arduous and his sufferings infinitely more severe in the Cause of the Country than those of Jackson— But such is the nature of popular applause— General Brown died Commander in chief of the Army; and probably Jackson would never have been any thing more, had not Congress, by reducing the army dismissed him from his Military Station— My Son Charles came out from Boston, to dine and spend the night here— I employed the afternoon in reading over that part of Marshall’s life of Washington, which preceded the commencement of our Revolution. I resumed also the sketch introductory to the Discourse upon the life and character of La Fayette, which I had begun, on the 4th. of this month, and which since that day has remained untouched— I fear the thought is too unwieldy to be fully carried out by me— I find in the newspapers notice of the death of Edmund Charles Genet, to whom I was once, forty years ago, a political antagonist—and that of B. F. Deming, a member of the House of Representatives of the United States from Vermont.
22. V. Tuesday.

My Son Charles returned this morning to Boston with a promise that he would come out again next Friday— He took with him my Letter Book, to copy the Letters that I may send him— I had a Letter from Elisha Thayer of Dedham requesting me to furnish him with extracts from the old Book of Braintree town Records, of all the entries of births, deaths and marriages of Benjamin Tompson, and his family— He was the town Clerk from the 10th. of Octr. 1687—three years and again from 1696 to 1699. I undertook this morning to make the extracts; and they engaged me for three or four hours— The entries are in a state of confusion almost inextricable. My nephews Isaac Hull and John Quincy came this morning and again at the high tide at one O’Clock, and I bathed with them at Mr Greenleafs wharf— They also dined with me, and visited my garden with me after dinner— There had been since yesterday another great change of weather from very cool to close and sultry—after dinner I was in such a state of lassitude that I found it impossible to write— I attempted to read, but could take no interest in any thing— I looked over the Annual Register for 1758 to find some historical facts of 1757— Then Marshall History of the British Colonies in America separated from his Life of Washington— Then in Beloe’s Herodotus an account of the Median Empire, amusing, but too fabulous, and finally Madame de Genlis’s preface and introduction to the Memoirs of the Marquis de Dangeau. Somewhat unexpectedly I found there a warm panegyric upon the character of Louis the 14th. and rather an angry charge against Fenelon, for his indirect Satire upon the Government and court of Louis, in his Telemaque— She cites the Eulogy of Fenelon by D’Alembert as Secretary of the French Academy, and refers to a Manuscript Letter there stated by him to have been written by Fenelon to Louis, more direct and explicit, and so bitterly censorious, that it is scarcely conceivable that Fenelon should have dared send it to the king;
or that he should have received it without sending the writer to the Bastille. It is exactly in the style, of the Letter of Junius to George the third— This reading employed me till near Sunset; when I called to see Mr G. W. Beale, but he was not at home. I saw his daughter Ann who keeps his house— I then walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and there spent the remainder of the Evening— Her daughter Elizabeth C. Adams arrived last evening; returning from New-Orleans— Dr. Woodward was there.
23. V. Wednesday.

I wrote a serious Letter to my Son John—made a copy of it, and despatched it by the mail— So little of any thing that I ever deliberately projected in my life has ever succeeded, that I cannot indulge a hope of success on this occasion— The Circumstances of the time impose a duty upon me, which I must discharge— My own Life, has been upon the whole fortunate down even to the present time—or rather I would say that a kind and indulgent Providence has shaped my fortunes more auspiciously than I could have done by any Prudence of my own— As my years advance my prospects decay; my hopes are blasted with disappointment; my trials sharpen with severity, and the forethought of what is to come after me, bears me down with a burthen beyond endurance— Solitude quickens my fears— I have lost my appetite— I am losing my sleep— I feel as if heavy calamities were impending over me, and the Letters from my wife aggravate all my apprehensions— If not a Sparrow falls to the ground but by the decree of superior goodness and wisdom, may I not ask for mercy or for resignation? what I do, will come to nought—may not a ray of comfort and relief beam from a quarter where it cannot now be foreseen?— Solomon Thayer called upon me this morning— It has been in my power to serve him— I obtained for him a small increase of pension as a Soldier of the Revolution, and he is grateful— He offered me any service that it may be in his power to render me; and this is better than gold— In the afternoon Alexander Townsend came out from Boston to see me— He has just returned from Bangor in the State of Maine, where he went upon a Summer excursion, and where he told me he had made an investment on speculation to the amount of thirty-five thousand dollars— By a purchase of grounds from which the houses have been swept away by fire, with the intention of rebuilding upon it fourteen houses— Townsend is a man of college education, of classical taste, of literary dispositions, of self confiding understanding, and of singular destitution of judgment— He has been a very disinterested, and almost solitary political friend of mine, without defection when others have deserted me— But his opinions do not agree with mine, upon the recent disturbances at the University— After he went away Mr Price Greenleaf came, and visited my Garden with me— He promised to come, and bud some of my trees for me— I paid an Evening visit at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— His Sister Mrs Haven, with two daughters were there.
24. V. Thursday.

I wrote to my wife, in answer to her Letters of the 16th. and 19th. and enclosed it to my Son Charles at Boston. Visited my Garden and Nursery of seedlings which are filling with stocks of forest and fruit trees, from six years old, down to shoots of the present year, from my plantations of the last. I find full occupation for two hours merely in inspecting
them— Isaac Hull Adams was here, and told me that his brother John Quincy had broken out yesterday with a poisonous eruption, attributed to his having climbed a tree entwined with ivy— He said also that his Sister Elizabeth had dismissed Mr Gourgas— I resumed my Diary Index now nearly a year in arrear, and while engaged upon it was struck with the decay of my Memory, with regard to incidents even of the last year— And does not—must not the judgment, and the imagination decay with the Memory? for what is imagination but a combination of ideas lodged in the mind by Memory? and what is judgment, but a comparison and selection of ideas lodged in the mind by the same faculty? This afternoon Mr Peter Lanman called upon me, and mentioned that a Mr Benjamin was proposing to publish a monthly Magazine for which he had obtained about one hundred subscribers, and for which he wished me to write an introductory Article— This task I declined having already upon my hands more writing to do than will be for my credit, or I fear for the good of mankind— The burden imposed upon me by the Assignment of the two Houses of Congress to deliver before them an Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette is so oppressive that I sink under it— I can undertake nothing else and shrink from the performances of that— This Mr Lanman is a very old, though yet only a transient acquaintance about the 10th. of September 1789. forty-five years ago, I casually met him as a fellow passenger in a packet Sloop from Providence to Newport, which passage we were nearly 24 hours in performing; a dead calm, having left us to drift down in two tides; laying at anchor the two others, which would else have drifted us back to Providence— There were several incidents which occurred that day and night which left impressions on my mind, never since forgotten—but Mr Lanman was bound to Norwich in Connecticut, where he lived, and I to New-York to visit my father— We parted at Newport, and I saw nor heard more of Mr Lanman, for upwards of thirty years— When I was Secretary of State in 1819. his brother James Lanman, was a member of the Senate of the United States, and he himself was afterwards an applicant for a consular appointment— In February 1824. he was appointed Consul at Kingston in the Island of Jamaica; where he remained but a short time. I had again seen nor heard nothing of him since then, till he now presented himself to me upon this singular errand. His appearance is old and somewhat haggard— I have seen him in youth, in waning manhood and in old age—pass like three successive apparitions before me: and the changes in his aspect, are as a mirror in which I can see my own— He is within a year or two of my own age— I rode up to Mr Solomon Thayer’s, and saw an Acre and a half of what he calls his Ray wheat— I took also from his trees, twigs of Iron and Pound Pears, and of the Wollaston Apple that of the last year, budded for me having failed— Called going and returning at Mr Brigham’s shop, and received two years interest on my Quincy Canal Notes— Mr G. W. Beale spent an hour of the Evening with me
25. V. Friday.

Isaac H. Adams was here this morning, and said his brothers poisonous eruption was worse this day, than it was yesterday— I received another distressing Letter from my wife, respecting the sickness of my Son John, of his wife; of their child Louisa and of my wife’s brother Thomas B. Johnson— This continual stream of melancholy intelligence, not only unfits me for all enjoyment, but disqualifies me for
useful occupation, and discomposes me to such a degree that I can neither read write, nor meditate upon the subjects of my choice— I wrote again to my Son John— His brother Charles came out from Boston, and gave some diversion to my thoughts—and Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in the afternoon, and budded for me some Stocks, of Apples, Pears and Cherries— His buds of the year before last, and his grafts of the last year have almost all succeeded; but all the buds of the last Summer have failed— Mr Greenleaf took tea, and spent the Evening with us— I read only a few pages of Dangeau’s Memoirs, which are full of Solemn trifles— They exhibit all the interior of the Court of Louis the 14th. beginning in April 1684— The king’s journies to Fontainebleau and Marly; his visits to Paris—his Opera’s Comedies and Balls, his gratuities, promotions, and condescensions, his receptions of Ambassadors, and his royal irritabilities fill the book— The smartest things that I find in it are the casual remarks of the Doge of Venice, whom he compelled to come to Versailles and make some apology to him— Voltaire says that this Doge was un homme d’Esprit—and so he appears in this Book.
26. V. Saturday

Another disspiriting Letter from my wife, and I wrote another supplicatory Letter to my Son John— The thoughts of the future haunt me in my dreams; of which I had a cruel one last Night: yet my only enquiry must be what to do—and when I can ascertain that to do it, and submit to the Will of Heaven. Mr Quincy the President of Harvard University was here, and I had a long conversation with him, on what is to be done with the disturbances among the Students there— The faculty, that is to say Mr Quincy, for the responsibility rests with him, have turned over, several of the Students, guilty of breaches of the Peace, to the Court of criminal Jurisdiction of the County; and three of them are under indictment by the Grand Jury of Middlesex, to be tried in September They have also dismissed and expelled several others— Eight particularly from the Senior Class— The others have received since they left College, their parts for Commencement, and there are instigations to them to combine, and refuse to perform— I asked Mr Quincy, if he had looked forward to that contingency, to be prepared for it— He said he had no reason to expect any such movement— I told him I should not be without apprehension of further disorder till the commencement shall be over— I urged him also to be prepared at the Meeting of the Overseers next Thursday, to sustain the measure of prosecuting in the Court of Criminal Jurisdiction, Students under matriculation at the University. He said he did not consider that as a question to be discussed— The Law was plain, and if the Overseers chose to alter it, there was no obligation upon him to dissuade them from such an intention— I told him there was great diversity of Opinion, and some public excitement upon this question— That I believed it would be discussed— I hoped he would be ready for it; and my disposition would be to sustain him and the faculty, to the utmost extent of my power. He thanked me for this notice, and said he would be prepared both by argument, and by precedent to shew the necessity and expediency of resorting to the
Courts of criminal jurisdiction for the trial of criminal Students— He spoke of Alexander Townsend, as of an insane man, and of his shewing my Letter to him, to Edmund Quincy, the President’s Son, as a proof of his insanity— He spoke also of his own remarks upon Southern Students, which have been misrepresented, and to which an invidious application has been given— There is in truth among the Students a contumacious and insurgent Spirit, which he has been labouring to subdue, and which takes to defend itself the expedient of a personal attack upon him. His intentions are upright, and his sense of his own duties deep and consciencious— He writes with great force, but his elocution is embarrassed and stammering— His present situation is very critical, and there is a strong disposition in the public mind to take side against him— At the Board of Overseers James T. Austin, bitterly hostile to him— Alexander H. Everett, not friendly to him, and George Blake, fond of speech-making will take the lead— My course as a friend of Mr Quincy, of the University and of good education, will be to act as little as possible—particularly to trust little to my own discretion— Isaac H. Adams was here this afternoon— I kept house the whole day owing to the extreme-heat of the weather; not exceeded this Summer— I could not write after dinner—nor read any thing more meditative than Dangeau’s Memoirs— There is curious matter in them—and some exceedingly ridiculous— See 17. Septr. 1690. the discovery, by the Bishop of Quebec of an Indian tribe with hair like Parrot’s feathers—and another Nation of Hunchback men, and lame women— This was the 37th. anniversary of my wedding day.
27. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Joseph Angier, this morning from 2. Corinthians 4.16—“but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed—day by day.” and in the afternoon from 2. Corinithians 6.2.—[“]behold now is the accepted time; behold now is the day of salvation.” sensible discourses—well read with propriety—with some pathos but not much animation. Mr Whitney has lost the attachment of his Parishioners which for nearly 30 years he enjoyed in a very eminent degree— His powers of composition, never great have been for some time exhausted— Several of the neighbouring clergymen, with whom he was in the practice of exchanging have made their congregations equally weary of them, and they have been dismissed— Mr Whitney’s Salary by the terms of his original Settlement in 1800 was 500 dollars a year— It has since been raised by consent of his parishioners to 750. and he has now agreed to reduce it again to 500. and to the remaining 250. the parish are to add an equal sum, to hire occasional assistance to supply his Pulpit one half the time— They give the occasional preachers ten dollars a day— The parish, or congregation have thinned off so that the house is never half filled; and besides the Episcopal Church rebuilt within the last two years, two new religious Societies have been formed, one of Universalits, and one of orthodox Calvinists, by each of which a new Church has been built— The building of these Churches makes a job for the builders, but their multiplication is the signal of the decline of the Religion— The singing choir at Mr Whitney’s have dwindled down from 35 or 40 to 10 or 12. and from 15 females down to seldom more than two— Mr Whitney this morning asked prayers for himself and his family, on account of the death, suddenly, of a brother, and this afternoon he gave notice that the Communion
would be administered, next Sunday.— I read the ninth Sermon of the fifth Volume of Saurin—for Whitsunday—upon the first discourse of St. Peter—very unsatisfactory—very artificial— The principal subject is the miraculous gift of tongue, conferred on the apostles, on the day of Pentecost: a subject that I never heard well treated in the Pulpit, and which perhaps cannot be well treated— This day was of still more intense heat than yesterday— I could do nothing out of the hours of public worship, but read, and I reviewed all the Sermons of Massillon, which I had read more than twenty years since— I was chiefly in search of a comparison between William the third and Jeroboam, and an invocation of curses upon Protestant Nations, which I remember, but could not find— In his funeral Eulogy upon the Dauphin, Son of Louis the 14th. and in that upon Louis the 14th. himself I found much matter for reflection.
28. IV:30. Monday.

The Night without sustaining the intense heat of the day, was yet not cool— Immediately after Sunrise, I walked to Mr Greenleaf’s wharf, and bathed and swam about five minutes: then walked home, and to take the cool of the morning, spent a couple of hours in my Garden and Nursery— I emptied the Earth from one of the earthen Pots in which I had last October planted a whole Wollaston Apple— It had rotted but not vegetated. The seeds within it were however yet alive I replanted it in the Summer-house cellar, and filled the Pot with new Earth, planting in it Limetree seeds; white strawberry seeds and one cherry— There came a tax collector, with a Bill of taxes for the years 1831 and 1832 for Land valued at 600 dollars in the town of Braintree— He thought it was my Pine-hill woodlots— I desired him to ascertain where and what land it was.— Isaac H. Adams came and took leave of me; about to return to West Point, his furlough being out— My Son Charles came out from Boston, while I was at dinner. Mr Alexander H. Everett, and Mr Hallett came early in the afternoon, and remained till dark— The conversation was all upon Politics, and contained nothing worthy of record.— There was much upon masonry and Anti-masonry— Something upon the prospects of the next Presidential Election— And not a little about the Bank— As they were going away, Mr Everett asked me, if I should attend, at the Meeting of the Overseers of the University, on Thursday Morning— I said it was my intention— He said he thought there would probably be some discussion. I asked him what he thought would be done— He said he supposed the Report which would be made by President Quincy would be referred to a Committee—nothing more was said— My Morning Bath and Visit to the Garden, and my afternoon visitors absorbed so much of my time for writing that I had scarcely a fragment left— I finished reading the first Volume of Dangeau’s Memoirs, and this engaged me to look into Voltaire’s Siécle de Louis quatorze, where I found much in a very different Style— I read also a few pages of the Life of La Fayette, of the early part of which, there is nothing satisfactory in the Book of Mr Sarrans— I received a Letter from my wife, which leads me to hope that by this day she is on her way from Washington.
29. V. Tuesday.

The day was cool, and in the afternoon there was a very copious thunder-shower which passed immediately over our heads from North to South. There was a single clap of thunder without echo and instantaneous after the flash— I visited my Garden, and Nursery with Charles.— I pointed out to him a seedling Apple tree of the second year, in the centre of the lowest, western side square bed of the Nursery, which came up from a whole Apple taken from the dwarf Apple tree in the Garden— This seedling came up about the first of May 1833. and by carefully shading it from the Sun, through that Summer, it was saved— A covering of Sea weed saved it from the Winter’s frost. It is now living, and may with care be preserved. My Garden and Nursery are now so filled with seedling trees, forest and fruit, from the first shoots of this Season to stocks of five years and six years standing, that a mere inspection of them gives me occupation two or three hours, without a perception of the passage of time— There are two or three new varieties of trees first appearing this Season, and which I have not ascertained.— I have eight or ten Nettle trees up in a row, where I planted the Spring before last the berries from the tree— The growth of these which are three and four years old is busy—and the leading shoot is winter killed, a foot or eighteen inches from the top— The Art of the Nursery and Seedsmen to make tall and strong Stems to their seedling trees, I still lack— My employment this day was without interruption of visitors, and the temperature of the atmosphere permitted me to write after dinner. I answered Letters from Leverett Saltonstall, and Stephen C. Phillips of Salem—gave each an hour to my daily diary and index, and wrote two pages, of the sketch for the discourse on the life and character of La Fayette. This I ought to do, every day; and scarcely do one day in ten— Mrs Kirk was taken ill this day, and Dr Woodward was here— The first flowers appeared upon the Althaea trees under my windows—
30. V. Wednesday.

My Son Charles went to Boston immediately after Breakfast the intended course of my occupations was interrupted, and I could not visit my garden this day— William Spear came to enquire concerning the numbers and price and rent of my pews in the Stone Meeting house, of which I have been obliged to take 34— I looked for the Deeds of them which I took from the Treasurer of the Society George W. Beale last Autumn; but could not find them— I asked Mr Spear to call again, and then the whole morning was absorbed, in examining all my Deeds and vouchers, to find those of the pews— I found them at last, but discovered that other private vouchers are missing— This will occasion another day’s search, and will give me occupation that ought not to be neglected—but it interrupts that in which I am now engaged— After dinner I rode to the Mount Wollaston farm, and Alpheus Spear being at Rock-Island I went there and found him in the barn getting in hay— He had given me among the Bills in payment of his rent one of ten dollars of the Suffolk Bank, which the declined receiving at the U.S. Branch Bank, as of doubtful authenticity. I shewed it to him, and he promised to give me other money for it— I then rode over and visited Mr John Bailey at Dorchester, and had with him two hours of conversation.
There is at present a great calm in the political world; and no prospects upon which I can dwell with satisfaction— The system of Administration for the Government of the Union, is radically and I believe irretrievably vitiated— Vitiated at the fountain. The succession to the Presidency absorbs all the National Interests, and the electioneering contests are becoming merely venal— My hopes of the long continuance of this Union are extinct— The people must go the way of all the world, and split up into an uncertain number of rival communities enemies in War, in Peace Friends— Were it otherwise, and were the future destinies of the Nation to be as prosperous and as glorious as they have been hitherto, my lease of life is so near its close that I should live to witness little of it— My own system of Administration, which was to make the National domain the inexhaustible fund for progressive and unceasing internal improvement has failed—systematically renounced, and denounced by the present Administration, it has been undisguisedly abandoned by H. Clay—ingloriously deserted by J. C. Calhoun, and silently given up by D. Webster— These are the opposition aspirants to the Presidential succession, not one of them having a system of Administration which he would now dare to avow, and at this time scarcely linked together by the brittle chain of common opposition, to the unprincipled absurdities of the present incumbent— In coming home this Evening from Mr Bailey’s I found it chilling cold.
31. Thursday— Boston and Quincy.— Overseers Meeting.

I received this morning by the mail, a Letter from my wife; written last Sunday, and announcing her intention, to leave Washington for this place, the next day— Thinking she might reach here this afternoon, I sent Wilson with the horses and Carriage to Dedham; to stay there till the Steam-boat Stages from Providence should arrive, and if she should be in one of them, to take her home; and if not to come in to Boston for me—this afternoon I went myself to Boston in the Hingham Stage, the Quincy Stage being full; and there were in the Stage with me, seven women, and three small children— I went to Charles’s Office, and he soon after came in from Medford— He agreed with me, to come out this Evening to Quincy with me, in the carriage, if it should come, and if not, with a Horse and Chaise to be hired by him— At ten O’Clock, I attended at the Council Chamber, the Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University— Lieutenant Governor Armstrong presided, and there were upwards of thirty members present. There was a debate of two hours upon the Question, whether the Meeting was public or private.— Alexander H. Everett, said an Editor of a public Journal, (Mr Hale, publisher of the Daily Advertiser,) wished to be admitted to take minutes of the proceedings of the Meeting— This started the question, and no one could tell whether the Meetings were officially public or private— By the usage, the Meetings in the Council Chamber had always been de facto private; and by the by the recent usage when held in the Senate Chamber, or the Chamber of the House of Representatives they had been public— The Lieutenant Governor decided, though declaring his own experience very limited, and wishing for direction from the board, that the Meeting
was officially public, from which after much discussion, and various motions, which were set aside, and one to refer the whole subject to a Committee, which was rejected, Dr Charles Lowell appealed, and the decision was reversed by a majority, of at least three to one— The meeting was thus decided to be officially private— President Quincy then read his Statement of the proceedings of the faculty in relation to the disturbances which have recently taken place, among the Students— He declared however that he made it, on his own responsibility only, as a member of the Board, and without consulting either the faculty or the corporation— After it was read through, a pause of silence for several minutes ensued, and then Alexander H. Everett moved that it should be referred to a Committee of five, which was agreed to without opposition— The Chairman asked how the Committee should be appointed and was answered by the chairman. He named me, Governor Levi Lincoln, Dr John Codman, Coll. Benjamin T. Pickman and Alexander H. Everett. I asked to be excused from serving on the Committee: observing the inconvenience of my residence out of the City, and my own impression that upon the Statement that had been read, I saw nothing for a Committee to report, except a general approbation of what had been done— Remarking that the Statement itself, as it had been made without consultation with the faculty or the Corporation did not seem to me to present a case for the action of the Overseers, whose general functions I understood to be to revise the proceedings of the faculty and Corporation; and if they should now take the initiative of action would reverse that customary order— I was not sustained in my request to be excused, but Mr James Savage, Judge John Davis, and Richard Sullivan earnestly opposed it—and Mr Sullivan moved an additional Resolution charging the Committee to prepare an Address to the Public on the connection of morals with an University Education, and with a view to change the public opinion favourably to the limitation of the degrees to youths of exemplary character— The chairman asked if I persisted in my request to be excused— I said I should not— I had hoped the board would excuse me, but was mortified at having given rise to a debate; and as the sense of the board did not seem favourable to my wish I should say no more about it— The Meeting was then adjourned to Thursday the 21st. of August, ten O’Clock, at the same place— Dr Pierce the Secretary gave me the vote, and the Statement of President Quincy, and promised to send me a copy of the printed circular of the Seniors— He said it was my charge to notify Governor Lincoln of his appointment as a member of the Committee— I asked the other members of the Committee to remain after the adjournment of the Board, and they authorised me to agree with Governor Lincoln on a time of Meeting, which by Coll. Pickman’s invitation is to be at his house—and I am duly to notify them of the time— After the adjournment of the Meeting, I went to Charles’s Office again— Walking on the way with Dr Codman, he told me he regretted the recent erection of the new Trinitarian Church in Quincy; because he thought those who built it might have been satisfied with attending at the Episcopal Church; but
he hoped they would agree to differ— Charles dined with Edward Everett at Charlestown— I remained at his office till near four O’Clock reading an Article by Alexander H. Everett in the North American Review of this Month upon the old parties in this Country; containing much good sense, much sound political doctrine, and some errors both of opinion and of facts— Near four O’Clock I went to the Post-Office, and enquired if the Steam-boat Mail was in; but it was not; and to Fosters stables to see if Wilson and the Carriage were there; but they were not— Going to Dr Parkman’s to dine, I passed by the Common, upon which there was a crowd already collected to witness the ascension in a balloon of Mr Durant; and there was a continued stream of population, especially of women, moving to it— I dined with Dr George Parkman—Mr Webster, Alexander H. Everett, Franklin Dexter; Mr Furness of Philadelphia, Mr Hitchcock of Alabama, and Mr Francis Parkman, were the company, and as many more were missing from the table—truants to see the Ascension. As we were at the dessert, Durant went up in the Balloon; we all went to the top of the house, he was then about 100 feet perpendicular over our heads— The motion of the balloon was perceptible only by the diminution of its apparent size to the eye; we followed it till it had diminished to a speck and vanished. The Sensation to me was painful to me, when I considered the extreme dangers to which the man’s life was exposed— Dr Parkman invited me to pass the Night at his house, but I was too anxious to return home— Charles came for me about Sunset with a Horse and Chaise— The Steamboat Mail had arrived; but Wilson and the Carriage did not appear— I came home to Quincy with Charles, but my wife had not arrived, nor had Wilson returned with the Carriage— My forecast was a precaution inutile— I was very unwell almost the whole day, with a severe feverish headache, and a load upon the Spirits, almost beyond my strength to bear.

Day.— I rise at 5. O’Clock— Read 4 Chapters of Thomson’s Septuagint Bible. Now upon the Book of Esaias; more unintelligible and less sublime, than in King James’s Bible— I Journalize till 8 or 9. Breakfast— Visit my Garden, till interrupted by a call to business or to visitors— Read newspapers or write Letters, and idle away time till 2. P.M—dine—read after dinner desultory reading, and loll about till Sunset— Then visit my neighbours, or walk in the porch, or in my chamber till ten, when I retire to bed— The heat of the weather has disqualified, and unnerved me hitherto almost constantly since my return. My attempts to write upon the Life and character of La Fayette is almost every day protracted, and so is even the effort to redeem the errors of my Diary Index— My health [symbols] is better than it has been for several years, and if it may be continued to me, there will be no excuse for me left to palliate or permit negligence.
